natural problem: In the game Deal or No Deal, participants choose a box at random from a set of $26,$ one containing each of the following values: \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}\hline\$.01&\$1,000\\\hline\$1&\$5,000\\\hline\$5&\$10,000\\\hline\$10&\$25,000\\\hline\$25&\$50,000\\\hline\$50&\$75,000\\\hline\$75&\$100,000\\\hline\$100&\$200,000\\\hline\$200&\$300,000\\\hline\$300&\$400,000\\\hline\$400&\$500,000\\\hline\$500&\$750,000\\\hline\$750&\$1,000,000\\\hline\end{tabular} After choosing a box, participants eliminate other boxes by opening them, showing the amount of money in the box to the crowd, and then removing that box (and its money!) from the game. What is the minimum number of boxes a participant needs to eliminate in order to have a half chance of holding at least $\$100,\!000$ as his or her chosen box?
natural solution: Seven of the boxes contain at least this amount. If a participant is going to be holding one of these boxes with a probability of $1/2,$ there can be at most $7$ other boxes left. This means that at least $26-7-7=\boxed{12}$ boxes must be eliminated.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes total_boxes :: nat
and high_value_boxes :: nat
and remaining_boxes :: nat
and probability :: real
assumes h0 : "total_boxes = 26"
and h1 : "high_value_boxes = 12"
and h2 : "probability = high_value_boxes / remaining_boxes"
and h3 : "probability \<ge> 1/2"
shows  "remaining_boxes \<le> 14"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 In the game Deal or No Deal, participants choose a box at random from a set of $26,$ one containing each of the following values: \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}\hline\$.01&\$1,000\\\hline\$1&\$5,000\\\hline\$5&\$10,000\\\hline\$10&\$25,000\\\hline\$25&\$50,000\\\hline\$50&\$75,000\\\hline\$75&\$100,000\\\hline\$100&\$200,000\\\hline\$200&\$300,000\\\hline\$300&\$400,000\\\hline\$400&\$500,000\\\hline\$500&\$750,000\\\hline\$750&\$1,000,000\\\hline\end{tabular} After choosing a box, participants eliminate other boxes by opening them, showing the amount of money in the box to the crowd, and then removing that box (and its money!) from the game. What is the minimum number of boxes a participant needs to eliminate in order to have a half chance of holding at least $\$100,\!000$ as his or her chosen box? The final Answer is 12
 ### Proof
 Seven of the boxes contain at least this amount. If a participant is going to be holding one of these boxes with a probability of $1/2,$ there can be at most $7$ other boxes left. This means that at least $26-7-7=\boxed{12}$ boxes must be eliminated.
 *)

theorem
fixes total_boxes :: nat
and high_value_boxes :: nat
and remaining_boxes :: nat
and probability :: real
assumes h0 : "total_boxes = 26"
and h1 : "high_value_boxes = 12"
and h2 : "probability = high_value_boxes / remaining_boxes"
and h3 : "probability \<ge> 1/2"
shows  "remaining_boxes \<le> 14"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: There are 26 total boxes, and 12 of them contain high-value items. If the probability of choosing a high-value item is greater than or equal to 1/2, what is the maximum number of remaining boxes? The final answer is 14.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes boxes_eliminated :: nat
assumes h0 : "26 = 14 + boxes_eliminated"
and h1 : "14 / (26 - boxes_eliminated) \<le> 1 / 2"
shows  "boxes_eliminated = 12"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 In the game Deal or No Deal, participants choose a box at random from a set of $26,$ one containing each of the following values: \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}\hline\$.01&\$1,000\\\hline\$1&\$5,000\\\hline\$5&\$10,000\\\hline\$10&\$25,000\\\hline\$25&\$50,000\\\hline\$50&\$75,000\\\hline\$75&\$100,000\\\hline\$100&\$200,000\\\hline\$200&\$300,000\\\hline\$300&\$400,000\\\hline\$400&\$500,000\\\hline\$500&\$750,000\\\hline\$750&\$1,000,000\\\hline\end{tabular} After choosing a box, participants eliminate other boxes by opening them, showing the amount of money in the box to the crowd, and then removing that box (and its money!) from the game. What is the minimum number of boxes a participant needs to eliminate in order to have a half chance of holding at least $\$100,\!000$ as his or her chosen box? The final Answer is 12
 ### Proof
 Seven of the boxes contain at least this amount. If a participant is going to be holding one of these boxes with a probability of $1/2,$ there can be at most $7$ other boxes left. This means that at least $26-7-7=\boxed{12}$ boxes must be eliminated.
 *)

theorem
fixes boxes_eliminated :: nat
assumes h0 : "26 = 14 + boxes_eliminated"
and h1 : "14 / (26 - boxes_eliminated) \<le> 1 / 2"
shows  "boxes_eliminated = 12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: There are a certain number of boxes to be eliminated. Initially, there are 26 boxes, and 14 boxes have been eliminated so far. If at least half of the remaining boxes must be eliminated, how many boxes need to be eliminated in total? The final answer is 12.

assumes h0 : "26 - boxes_eliminated = remaining_boxes"
and h1 : "prob_of_holding_at_least_100000 = real(remaining_boxes_with_at_least_100000) / real(remaining_boxes)"
and h2 : "prob_of_holding_at_least_100000 \<ge> 1 / 2"
shows  "boxes_eliminated = 12"

fixes boxes_eliminated :: nat
assumes h0 : "26 - boxes_eliminated = remaining_boxes"

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes num_boxes :: nat and prob :: real
assumes h0 : "num_boxes = 26"
and h1 : "prob = 0.5"
shows  "minimum_eliminated_boxes = 12"
a_3.formal solution:

 In the game Deal or No Deal, participants choose a box at random from a set of $26,$ one containing each of the following values: \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}\hline\$.01&\$1,000\\\hline\$1&\$5,000\\\hline\$5&\$10,000\\\hline\$10&\$25,000\\\hline\$25&\$50,000\\\hline\$50&\$75,000\\\hline\$75&\$100,000\\\hline\$100&\$200,000\\\hline\$200&\$300,000\\\hline\$300&\$400,000\\\hline\$400&\$500,000\\\hline\$500&\$750,000\\\hline\$750&\$1,000,000\\\hline\end{tabular} After choosing a box, participants eliminate other boxes by opening them, showing the amount of money in the box to the crowd, and then removing that box (and its money!) from the game.  ### Proof
 Seven of the boxes contain at least this amount. If a participant is going to be holding one of these boxes with a probability of $1/2,$ there can be at most $7$ other boxes left. This means that at least $26-7-7=\boxed{12}$ boxes must be eliminated.
 *)

theorem
fixes num_boxes :: nat and prob :: real
assumes h0 : "num_boxes = 26"
and h1 : "prob = 0.5"
shows  "minimum_eliminated_boxes = 12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: There are 26 boxes and the probability of eliminating one box is 0.5. Find the minimum number of boxes that can be eliminated. The final answer is 12.

a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 In the game Deal or No Deal, participants choose a box at random from a set of $26,$ one containing each of the following values: \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}\hline\$.01&\$1,000\\\hline\$1&\$5,000\\\hline\$5&\$10,000\\\hline\$10&\$25,000\\\hline\$25&\$50,000\\\hline\$50&\$75,000\\\hline\$75&\$100,000\\\hline\$100&\$200,000\\\hline\$200&\$300,000\\\hline\$300&\$400,000\\\hline\$400&\$500,000\\\hline\$500&\$750,000\\\hline\$750&\$1,000,000\\\hline\end{tabular} After choosing a box, participants eliminate other boxes by opening them, showing the amount of money in the box to the crowd, and then removing that box (and its money!) from the game. What is the minimum number of boxes a participant needs to eliminate in order to have a half chance of holding at least $\$100,\!000$ as his or her chosen box? The final Answer is 12
 ### Proof
 Seven of the boxes contain at least this amount. If a participant is going to be holding one of these boxes with a probability of $1/2,$ there can be at most $7$ other boxes left. This means that at least $26-7-7=\boxed{12}$ boxes must be eliminated.
 *)

theorem
fixes num_boxes_eliminated :: nat
assumes h0 : "26"
and h1 : "{0.01, 1, 5, 10, 25, 50, 75, 100, 200, 300, 400, 500, 750, 1000, 5000, 10000, 25000, 50000, 75000, 100000, 200000, 300000, 400000, 500000, 750000, 1000000}"
and h2 : "0.5"
shows  "num_boxes_eliminated = 12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: In a game, there are 26 boxes with the following amounts inside: {$0.01, 1, 5, 10, 25, 50, 75, 100, 200, 300, 400, 500, 750, 1000, 5000, 10000, 25000, 50000, 75000, 100000, 200000, 300000, 400000, 500000, 750000, 1000000$}. If a player eliminates boxes worth half of the total amount or less, how many boxes will be eliminated? The final answer is 12.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes num_eliminated_boxes :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall> box \<in> {1..26}. box_has_value box"
and h1 : "chosen_box_value \<ge> 100000"
and h2 : "P(chosen_box_value \<ge> 100000) \<ge> 1/2"
shows  "num_eliminated_boxes \<ge> 12"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 In the game Deal or No Deal, participants choose a box at random from a set of $26,$ one containing each of the following values: \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}\hline\$.01&\$1,000\\\hline\$1&\$5,000\\\hline\$5&\$10,000\\\hline\$10&\$25,000\\\hline\$25&\$50,000\\\hline\$50&\$75,000\\\hline\$75&\$100,000\\\hline\$100&\$200,000\\\hline\$200&\$300,000\\\hline\$300&\$400,000\\\hline\$400&\$500,000\\\hline\$500&\$750,000\\\hline\$750&\$1,000,000\\\hline\end{tabular} After choosing a box, participants eliminate other boxes by opening them, showing the amount of money in the box to the crowd, and then removing that box (and its money!) from the game. What is the minimum number of boxes a participant needs to eliminate in order to have a half chance of holding at least $\$100,\!000$ as his or her chosen box? The final Answer is 12
 ### Proof
 Seven of the boxes contain at least this amount. If a participant is going to be holding one of these boxes with a probability of $1/2,$ there can be at most $7$ other boxes left. This means that at least $26-7-7=\boxed{12}$ boxes must be eliminated.
 *)

theorem
fixes num_eliminated_boxes :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall> box \<in> {1..26}. box_has_value box"
and h1 : "chosen_box_value \<ge> 100000"
and h2 : "P(chosen_box_value \<ge> 100000) \<ge> 1/2"
shows  "num_eliminated_boxes \<ge> 12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: In a game with 26 boxes, each box has a value assigned to it. If the probability of the chosen box having a value greater than or equal to 100,000 is at least 1/2, find the minimum number of boxes that must be eliminated from the game. The final answer is 12.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes boxes_total boxes_eliminated :: nat
assumes h0 : "boxes_total = 26"
and h1 : "half_chance = (1::real) / 2"
and h2 : "prob_at_least_100000 boxes_eliminated = 
          (count_boxes_with_at_least_100000 (boxes_total - boxes_eliminated)) / (boxes_total - boxes_eliminated)"
and h3 : "prob_at_least_100000 boxes_eliminated \<ge> half_chance"
shows  "boxes_eliminated = 12"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 In the game Deal or No Deal, participants choose a box at random from a set of $26,$ one containing each of the following values: \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}\hline\$.01&\$1,000\\\hline\$1&\$5,000\\\hline\$5&\$10,000\\\hline\$10&\$25,000\\\hline\$25&\$50,000\\\hline\$50&\$75,000\\\hline\$75&\$100,000\\\hline\$100&\$200,000\\\hline\$200&\$300,000\\\hline\$300&\$400,000\\\hline\$400&\$500,000\\\hline\$500&\$750,000\\\hline\$750&\$1,000,000\\\hline\end{tabular} After choosing a box, participants eliminate other boxes by opening them, showing the amount of money in the box to the crowd, and then removing that box (and its money!) from the game. What is the minimum number of boxes a participant needs to eliminate in order to have a half chance of holding at least $\$100,\!000$ as his or her chosen box? The final Answer is 12
 ### Proof
 Seven of the boxes contain at least this amount. If a participant is going to be holding one of these boxes with a probability of $1/2,$ there can be at most $7$ other boxes left. This means that at least $26-7-7=\boxed{12}$ boxes must be eliminated.
 *)

theorem
fixes boxes_total boxes_eliminated :: nat
assumes h0 : "boxes_total = 26"
and h1 : "half_chance = (1::real) / 2"
and h2 : "prob_at_least_100000 boxes_eliminated = 
          (count_boxes_with_at_least_100000 (boxes_total - boxes_eliminated)) / (boxes_total - boxes_eliminated)"
and h3 : "prob_at_least_100000 boxes_eliminated \<ge> half_chance"
shows  "boxes_eliminated = 12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: There are 26 boxes, each containing a certain amount of money. If you eliminate a number of boxes, what is the minimum number of boxes you need to eliminate so that the probability of the remaining boxes containing at least $100,000 is at least 50%? The final answer is 12.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes num_boxes total_boxes :: nat
and p :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "total_boxes = 26"
and h1 : "sum p {1..total_boxes} = 1"
and h2 : "num_boxes = (LEAST n. (\<Sum> i = 1..(total_boxes - n). p i) \<ge> 0.5)"
and h3 : "\<forall> i \<le> total_boxes - num_boxes. p i * 100000 \<le> 100000"
shows  "num_boxes = 12"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 In the game Deal or No Deal, participants choose a box at random from a set of $26,$ one containing each of the following values: \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}\hline\$.01&\$1,000\\\hline\$1&\$5,000\\\hline\$5&\$10,000\\\hline\$10&\$25,000\\\hline\$25&\$50,000\\\hline\$50&\$75,000\\\hline\$75&\$100,000\\\hline\$100&\$200,000\\\hline\$200&\$300,000\\\hline\$300&\$400,000\\\hline\$400&\$500,000\\\hline\$500&\$750,000\\\hline\$750&\$1,000,000\\\hline\end{tabular} After choosing a box, participants eliminate other boxes by opening them, showing the amount of money in the box to the crowd, and then removing that box (and its money!) from the game. What is the minimum number of boxes a participant needs to eliminate in order to have a half chance of holding at least $\$100,\!000$ as his or her chosen box? The final Answer is 12
 ### Proof
 Seven of the boxes contain at least this amount. If a participant is going to be holding one of these boxes with a probability of $1/2,$ there can be at most $7$ other boxes left. This means that at least $26-7-7=\boxed{12}$ boxes must be eliminated.
 *)

theorem
fixes num_boxes total_boxes :: nat
and p :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "total_boxes = 26"
and h1 : "sum p {1..total_boxes} = 1"
and h2 : "num_boxes = (LEAST n. (\<Sum> i = 1..(total_boxes - n). p i) \<ge> 0.5)"
and h3 : "\<forall> i \<le> total_boxes - num_boxes. p i * 100000 \<le> 100000"
shows  "num_boxes = 12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: There are 26 boxes, each containing a certain percentage of items. The sum of the percentages of all boxes is 100%. Find the smallest number of boxes that together contain at least 50% of the items, given that for each box, the percentage of items in that box is at most 100,000 times smaller than the total number of items. The final answer is 12 boxes.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes box_count total_boxes :: nat
assumes h0 : "total_boxes = 26"
and h1 : "box_count boxes_needed_for_half_chance"
and h2 : "half_chance_probability = 1 / 2"
and h3 : "box_count >= 12"
shows  "boxes_needed_for_half_chance = 12"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 In the game Deal or No Deal, participants choose a box at random from a set of $26,$ one containing each of the following values: \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}\hline\$.01&\$1,000\\\hline\$1&\$5,000\\\hline\$5&\$10,000\\\hline\$10&\$25,000\\\hline\$25&\$50,000\\\hline\$50&\$75,000\\\hline\$75&\$100,000\\\hline\$100&\$200,000\\\hline\$200&\$300,000\\\hline\$300&\$400,000\\\hline\$400&\$500,000\\\hline\$500&\$750,000\\\hline\$750&\$1,000,000\\\hline\end{tabular} After choosing a box, participants eliminate other boxes by opening them, showing the amount of money in the box to the crowd, and then removing that box (and its money!) from the game. What is the minimum number of boxes a participant needs to eliminate in order to have a half chance of holding at least $\$100,\!000$ as his or her chosen box? The final Answer is 12
 ### Proof
 Seven of the boxes contain at least this amount. If a participant is going to be holding one of these boxes with a probability of $1/2,$ there can be at most $7$ other boxes left. This means that at least $26-7-7=\boxed{12}$ boxes must be eliminated.
 *)

theorem
fixes box_count total_boxes :: nat
assumes h0 : "total_boxes = 26"
and h1 : "box_count boxes_needed_for_half_chance"
and h2 : "half_chance_probability = 1 / 2"
and h3 : "box_count >= 12"
shows  "boxes_needed_for_half_chance = 12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: There are 26 boxes in total. What is the minimum number of boxes you need to pick to have at least a 50% chance of getting a specific box? The final answer is 12.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n_boxes :: nat and prob :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "n_boxes = 26"
and h1 : "prob n = card {x. x \<in> {1..26} \<and> x \<ge> n} / n_boxes"
and h2 : "prob n \<ge> 1/2"
shows  "n = 12"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 In the game Deal or No Deal, participants choose a box at random from a set of $26,$ one containing each of the following values: \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}\hline\$.01&\$1,000\\\hline\$1&\$5,000\\\hline\$5&\$10,000\\\hline\$10&\$25,000\\\hline\$25&\$50,000\\\hline\$50&\$75,000\\\hline\$75&\$100,000\\\hline\$100&\$200,000\\\hline\$200&\$300,000\\\hline\$300&\$400,000\\\hline\$400&\$500,000\\\hline\$500&\$750,000\\\hline\$750&\$1,000,000\\\hline\end{tabular} After choosing a box, participants eliminate other boxes by opening them, showing the amount of money in the box to the crowd, and then removing that box (and its money!) from the game. What is the minimum number of boxes a participant needs to eliminate in order to have a half chance of holding at least $\$100,\!000$ as his or her chosen box? The final Answer is 12
 ### Proof
 Seven of the boxes contain at least this amount. If a participant is going to be holding one of these boxes with a probability of $1/2,$ there can be at most $7$ other boxes left. This means that at least $26-7-7=\boxed{12}$ boxes must be eliminated.
 *)

theorem
fixes n_boxes :: nat and prob :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "n_boxes = 26"
and h1 : "prob n = card {x. x \<in> {1..26} \<and> x \<ge> n} / n_boxes"
and h2 : "prob n \<ge> 1/2"
shows  "n = 12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: In a game, there are 26 boxes, numbered from 1 to 26. The probability of picking a box with a number greater than or equal to $n$ is given by $\frac{\text{number of boxes with numbers } \geq n}{26}$. Find the smallest value of $n$ such that the probability is at least $\frac{1}{2}$. The final answer is 12.
